Award.AwardTitle: Research in Quantum Field Theory: Relativistic Matter in a Magnetic Field
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses current issues of interest concerning the structure of the Universe. The investigator and his students will focus on the study of matter in compact stars, as natural laboratories that provide extreme densities and strong magnetic fields. One of the important components of the project concerns the training of graduate and undergraduate students by involving them into a modern research program in theoretical nuclear physics. The students are expected to develop strong analytical and problem-solving skills that will be applied in their future careers in industry or academia. The integration of the principle investigator's research with education at the Arizona State University with a substantial enrollment of underrepresented groups of students will contribute to a high-quality education in science and engineering, as well as to the development of human resources in the region.

This project will apply quantum field theoretical methods to study fundamental properties of relativistic matter in magnetic fields. The corresponding relativistic types of matter with strong magnetic fields are relevant for the phenomenology of compact stars, the evolution of the Early Universe, and the physics of relativistic heavy ion collisions. Therefore, the project will add to a deeper understanding of numerous phenomena in the natural world and will expand the knowledge about the phases of strongly interacting matter and their role in the cosmos. The theoretical methods and research outcomes of this project will also extend beyond the realm of theoretical nuclear physics. In particular, the results of these studies will be useful in the context of quasi-relativistic condensed matter materials, which hold a great promise for future applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was dedicated to theoretical studies of anomalous properties of relativistic and pseudo-relativistic forms of matter in magnetic fields. Example of physical systems with such forms of matter include degenerate baryonic matter inside compact stars, hot plasma in the early Universe, fireballs of quark-gluon plasma produced in relativistic heavy ion collisions, and even some novel solid state materials (e.g., Dirac and Weyl semimetals). 

Among the main results of the project are (i) development of a consistent chiral kinetic theory framework for applications in solid state physics, (ii) development of consistent chiral hydrodynamics for applications in solid state physics, (iii) development of dissipative chiral hydrodynamics for the relativistic high-energy systems, (iv) detailed studies of anomalous transport properties of Dirac and Weyl semimetals, (v) proposal of several novel methods for controlling and manipulating chiral properties of matter (e.g., a pseudomagnetic lens, see the image attached), (vi) establishing the origin of dissipative Fermi arc transport in Weyl semimetals, and more. All of these contribute to the new fundamental knowledge on chiral forms of matter. 

The results of the project demonstrate that many observable properties of chiral matter are directly affected by quantum anomalies. For example, the latter could be responsible for a dynamical generation of the magnetic field in the early Universe and in compact starts. Even more surprisingly, the anomalies could be responsible for numerous exotic features of solid state materials, such as Dirac and Weyl semimetals. This is very important in part because the latter could have a direct impact on the future development of quantum materials with valuable technological properties. 

The project was used as a platform for educating and training undergraduate and graduate students. The participation in research helps students to acquire new knowledge, as well as to form strong analytical and problem solving skills. This is particularly valuable for undergraduate students who usually participate in small projects via honors contracts. During the duration of the project, the PI also had two doctoral-level graduate students who worked on the project. One of them finished the program and defended a Ph.D. degree in May 2016. The other student, who is still finishing a research project on dissipative chiral hydrodynamics, will graduate tentatively in 2019.
